com.github.unix_junkie.javafs

Class FileSystem

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.unix_junkie.javafs.FileSystem
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AutoCloseable

    public final class FileSystem
extends Object
implements AutoCloseable

    An abstract representation of a mounted file system. Please use either of create(Path, long), create(Path, long, BlockSize) and mount(Path) factory methods to get a file system instance.

    Author:
    Andrew ``Bass'' Shcheglov <mailto:andrewbass@gmail.com>
    See Also:
    create(Path, long), create(Path, long, BlockSize), mount(Path)

    • Method Detail

      • create

        public static FileSystem create(Path path,
                                long length)
                         throws IOException

        Creates a file system container specified by path and returns the created file system. The file system will use the block size which is the default for length. Use create(Path, long, BlockSize) is you need to specify a custom block size.

        Parameters:
        path - the path of the file system container; will be truncated if exists.
        length - the size of the file system container, in bytes.
        Returns:
        the created file system.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the underlying file channel can't be opened, or any other I/O error occurs.
        See Also:
        create(Path, long, BlockSize)

      • create

        public static FileSystem create(Path path,
                                long length,
                                BlockSize blockSize)
                         throws IOException

        Creates a file system container specified by path and returns the created file system.

        Parameters:
        path - the path of the file system container; will be truncated if exists.
        length - the size of the file system container, in bytes.
        blockSize - the file system block size.
        Returns:
        the created file system.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the underlying file channel can't be opened, or any other I/O error occurs.
        See Also:
        create(Path, long)

      • mount

        public static FileSystem mount(Path path)
                        throws IOException

        Mounts a file system container specified by path and returns the mounted file system.

        Parameters:
        path - the path of the file system container; will be truncated if exists.
        Returns:
        the mounted file system.
        Throws:
        IOException - if the underlying file channel can't be opened, file system metadata is corrupted (invalid block size, etc.), file system version is not supported, or any other I/O error occurs.

      • getBlockSize

        public BlockSize getBlockSize()

        Returns file system block size. Once the file system is created, its block size can't be changed.

        Returns:
        file system block size.

      • getBlockAddressSize

        public byte getBlockAddressSize()

        Returns block address size.

        For a 1.44M file system (4k blocks), 16-bit addressing is sufficient; inode table would be just 720 bytes.

        For a 32G file system (4k blocks again), 24-bit addressing is sufficient; inode table size is 24M.

        For a file system which is 7.99E large however (the maximum value which can be represented using Long.MAX_VALUE) and uses 64k blocks, 48-bit addressing will be required, and inode table size will be 768T.

        Returns:
        the number of bytes needed to identify a block within the inode table. The values returned will range from 1 (8-bit) to 8 (64-bit).

      • getBootSectorSize

        public int getBootSectorSize()

        Returns the size of file system boot sector, in bytes.

        Returns:
        the size of file system boot sector, in bytes.

      • getInodeTableSize

        public long getInodeTableSize()

        Returns the size of the inode table ("FAT"), in bytes.

        Returns:
        the size of the inode table ("FAT"), in bytes.
        See Also:
        getInodeTableSizeRounded()

      • getInodeTableSizeRounded

        public long getInodeTableSizeRounded()

        Returns the size of the inode table ("FAT") rounded to file system sector size, in bytes. The file system sector size is 512 bytes.

        Returns:
        the size of the inode table ("FAT") rounded to file system sector size, in bytes.
        See Also:
        getInodeTableSize()

      • getDataAreaLength

        public long getDataAreaLength()

        Returns the size of the data area (the area occupied by files), in bytes.

        Returns:
        the size of the data area (the area occupied by files), in bytes.

        public void close()
           throws IOException

      • getFileCount

        public long getFileCount()
                  throws IOException

        Returns the number of files on this file system. The number returned is at least 1 (empty file system with only a root directory).

        Returns:
        the number of files on this file system.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.

      • getFreeBlockCount

        public long getFreeBlockCount()
                       throws IOException

        Returns the number of free blocks.

        This operation is as inefficient as a similar operation on FAT family file systems: since there're no free space bitmaps, calculating free space results in full inode table scanning.

        Returns:
        the number of free blocks.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.
        See Also:
        getTotalBlockCount()

      • getRoot

        public Directory getRoot()
                  throws IOException

        Returns the file system's root directory.

        Returns:
        the file system's root directory.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs.

      • printStats

        public void printStats(@Nullable
                       PrintStream out)
                throws IOException

        Prints brief file system information to out.

        Parameters:
        out - the PrintStream file system information should be printed to.
        Throws:
        IOException - if file count or free block count can't be determined, or any other I/O error occurs.
